description: This dashboard is designed to match the counters mentioned in document published by QUEST SOFTWARE on "SQL Server Perfmon Counters of Interest"

panels.description:
< 80%. 
Percentage of processor time spent on SQL
Server process threads.You may also wish
to investigate other Process (sqlservr) such
as Private Bytes, Virtual Bytes, Working Set,
etc to get a fuller understanding of how
SQL Server allocates certain segments of
memory. Usually, these auxiliary counters
provide contextual information and are not
necessary for troubleshooting.

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;
select pc.collection_time_utc as time, 
		case when (pc.object = 'processor' and pc.counter in ('% Processor Time') and pc.instance = '_total') then '% Processor Time (os)'
			when (pc.object = 'process' and pc.counter in ('% Processor Time') and pc.instance = 'sqlservr') then '% Processor Time (sqlservr)'
			else null
			end as metric,
	--object, counter as metric, instance
	case when pc.object = 'processor' then pc.value else pc.value/(select count(*) from sys.dm_os_schedulers dos where status = 'VISIBLE ONLINE') end as value
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc) and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name' and
	 ((pc.object = 'processor' and pc.counter in ('% Processor Time') and pc.instance = '_total')
	or (pc.object = 'process' and pc.counter in ('% Processor Time') and pc.instance = 'sqlservr')
	)
	and pc.value > 0
order by time

panels.title: %Processor Time (SqlServer)

panels.description:
Number of threads waiting for CPU cycles,
where < 12 per CPU is good/fair, < 8 is better,
< 4 is best.

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;

select pc.collection_time_utc as time, 
	object + ': '+ counter as metric
	--,instance,
	,pc.value
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc) and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name' and
	 pc.object = 'system' and pc.counter in ('Processor Queue Length')
order by time

panels.title: System: Processor Queue Length

panels.description:
Unused physical memory (not page file).
Should be greater than 2 GB

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;

select pc.collection_time_utc as time, pc.value as [Available Memory]
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc)
and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name'
and pc.object = 'memory' and pc.counter = 'available mbytes'
ORDER BY time

panels.title: Memory - Available Mbytes

panels.description:
Pages Input/Sec
-- Should be less than 10
-- Reads from hard disk per second to resolve
hard pages.

Pages/Sec
Often referenced in older documentation.
Useful only in combination with Pages
Input/Sec, %Usage, %Usage Peak.

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;

select pc.collection_time_utc as time, counter as metric , pc.value
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc)
and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name'
and	pc.object = 'memory' and pc.counter in ('Pages Input/Sec','Pages/Sec')
ORDER BY time

panels.title: Memory - Pages Input/Sec, Pages/Sec

panels.description:
Paging File: %Usage
-- Should be less than 70%
-- Amount of Page File in use, which indicates
the server is substituting disk space for
memory.

Paging File: %Usage Peak
-- Should be less than 70%
-- Highest %Usage metric since the last time
the server was restarted.

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;

select pc.collection_time_utc as time, counter as metric , pc.value
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc)
and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name'
and pc.object = 'Paging File' and pc.counter in ('% Usage','% Usage Peak')
order by time

panels.title: Paging File Usage

panels.description:
SQLServer: SQL Statistics - Batch Requests/sec

The number of batch requests received per second, and is a good general indicator for the activity level of the SQL Server.
panels.title: Batch Requests/sec

panels.description:
Forwarded Records/sec -> Less than 10 per 100 Batch Requests/Sec
==> Identifies use of a pointer which has been created when variable length columns have caused a row to move to a new page in a heap.

Full Scans/sec => Monitors the number of full scans on tables or indexes. Ignore unless high CPU coincides with high scan rates. High scan rates may be caused by missing indexes, very small tables, or requests for too many records. A sudden increase in this value may indicate a statistics threshold has been reached, resulting in an index no longer being used.

Index Searches/sec -> 1 Full Scan/sec per 1k Index Searches/sec
=> Monitors the number of index searches when doing range scans, single index record fetches, and repositioning within an index. The threshold recommendation is strictly for OLTP workloads.

Page Splits/sec -> Less than 20 per 100 Batch Requests/sec
=> Monitors the number of page splits per second which occur due to overflowing index pages and should  be as low as possible. To avoid page splits, review table and index design to reduce non-sequential inserts or implement fill factor and pad_index to leave more empty space per page. 
=> NOTE: A high value for this counter is not bad in situations where many new pages are being created, since it includes new page allocations

Workfiles Created/sec -> Less than 20
=> Number of work files created per second, usually as a part of tempdb processing when working with hashing joins and other hashing operations. High values can indicate thrash in tempdb and poorly coded queries.

Worktables Created/sec -> Less than 20
=> Number of work tables created per second, usually as part of tempdb processing when working with spools such as table spools, index spools, etc.
panels.title: SQLServer:Access Methods

panels.description:
Memory Grants Outstanding => Total number of processes per second that have successfully acquired a workspace memory grant.

Memory Grants Pending -> Numbers higher than 0 indicate a lack of memory
=> Total number of processes per second waiting for a workspace memory grant.
panels.title: Memory Grants

panels.description:
Target Server Memory => Total amount of dynamic memory that server can consume

Total Server Memory => Total amount of dynamic memory consumed at moment by the server

Maximum Workspace Memory => Maxium amount of memory available for executing processes such as hash, sort, bulk copy, and index creation operations.

Granted Workspace Memory => Total amount of memory currently granted to executing processes such as hash, sort, bulk copy, and index creation operations.
panels.title: SQL Server: Memory Manager

panels.description: Current Disk Queue Length => Number of IO requests waiting for read/write disk operation to be processed
panels.title: Logical Disk (Current Disk Queue Length)

panels.description:
Avg Disk Sec/Read -> Less than 8 ms.
=> A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each read to disk where > 20 is poor, <20 is good/fair, <12 is better, and < 8 is best.

Avg Disk Sec/Write -> Less than 8 ms (non cached) & Less than 1 ms (cached)
=> A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each write to disk, where non-caches writes (> 20 poor, <20 failure, <12 better, <8 best) differ significantly from cached writes (>4 poor, <4 fair, <2 better, <1 best). 
For OLTP databases, the lower this number the better, especially for disks holding the transaction log.
panels.title: Logical Disk - Latency

panels.description: Bytes/Sec => The number of bytes read/written to disk
panels.title: Logical Disk - Throughput

panels.description: Current Disk Queue Length => Number of IO requests waiting for read/write disk operation to be processed
panels.title: Physical Disk (Current Disk Queue Length)

panels.description:
Avg Disk Sec/Read -> Less than 8 ms.
=> A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each read to disk where > 20 is poor, <20 is good/fair, <12 is better, and < 8 is best.

Avg Disk Sec/Write -> Less than 8 ms (non cached) & Less than 1 ms (cached)
=> A key measure of disk latency representing the average time, in milliseconds, of each write to disk, where non-caches writes (> 20 poor, <20 failure, <12 better, <8 best) differ significantly from cached writes (>4 poor, <4 fair, <2 better, <1 best). 
For OLTP databases, the lower this number the better, especially for disks holding the transaction log.
panels.title: Physical Disk - Latency

panels.description: Bytes/Sec => The number of bytes read/written to disk
panels.title: Physical Disk - Throughput

panels.description: Bytes Total/sec => The number of bytes sent and received over a specific network adapter, including framing characters. Be sure to record the throughput of your SQL Server's NIC card(s). Watch for this value possibly exceeding the NIC's specifications, especially when conducting large and/or multiple backups or copies to network drives. A high-speed network and/or a NIC dedicated to admin processes often alleviates this bottleneck. This counter is a sum of "Network Interface\\Bytes Received/sec" & "Network Interface\\Bytes Sent/sec". In some situations, you may wish to determine both inbound and outbound network traffic separately. This counter is particularly useful in iSCSI  environments where it can help to measure disk I/O when the NIC is dedicated to storage.
panels.title: Network Interface - Bytes Total/sec

panels.description: Log Bytes Flushed/sec => Total number of log bytes flushed per second. Useful for determining trends and utilization of the transaction log
panels.title: SqlServer:Databases - Log Bytes Flushed/sec

panels.description:
Log Flush Wait Time -> Should be equal to 0
=> Total wait time, in milliseconds, to write all transaction log pages.
panels.title: SqlServer:Databases -  Log Flush Wait Time

panels.description:
Log Flush Waits/sec -> Should be equal to 0.
=> Effectively, the number of times per second that SQL Server must wait for pages to be written to the transaction log

Log Flushes/sec => Technically, the number of log pages flushed to the transaction log per second

Log Growths -> Should be equal to 0.
=> Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been expanded. Each time the transaction log grows, all user activity must halt until the log growth completes. Therefore, you want log growths to occur during predefined maintenance windows rather than during general working hours.

Log Shrinks -> Should be equal to 0.
=> Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been shrunk

Log Truncations => Total number of times the transaction log has been truncated for the database specified. Truncations should happen during log backups or, on databases in simple recovery model, at checkpoint or the time period specified by recovery interval.

Percent Log Used -> Should be less than 80%.
=> Percentage of space in the log that is in use. Since all work in an OLTP database stops until writes can occur to the transaction log, it's a very good idea to ensure that the log never fills completely. Hence, the recommendation to keep the log under 80% full.
panels.title: SqlServer:Databases - Others

panels.description:
Auto-Param Attempts/sec => Number of auto-parameterization attempts per second. Total should be sum of the failed, safe, and unsafe auto-parameterizations. Auto-parameterization occurs when an instance of SQL Server attempts to reuse a cached plan for a previously executed query that is similar to, but not the same as, the current query.

Failed Auto-Params/sec => Number of failed auto-parameterization attempts per second. This should be small.

Safe Auto-Params/sec => Number of safe auto-parameterization attempts per second.

Unsafe Auto-Params/sec => A query is designated as unsafe when it has characteristics that prevents its cached plan from being shared.
panels.title: SQLServer:SQL Statistics - Auto Parameterization
SQL Server - SQL Statistics - Auto Parameterization

panels.description:
SQLServer: SQL Statistics - Batch Requests/sec

The number of batch requests received per second, and is a good general indicator for the activity level of the SQL Server.
panels.title: Batch Requests/sec

panels.description:
Page Life Expectancy -> Above 300.
=> Tells, on average, how many seconds SQL Server expects a data page to stay in cache. The target on an OLTP system should be at least 300 (5 min). When under 300, this may indicate poor index design (leading to increased disk I/O and less effective use of memory) or, simply, a potential shortage of memory.
panels.title: Page Life Expectancy

panels.description:
Free List Stalls/sec -> Less than 2.
=> Monitors the number of requests per second where data requests stall because no buffers are available. Any value above 2 means SQL Server needs more memory.

Lazy Writes/Sec -> Less than 20.
=> Monitors the number of times per second that the Lazy Writer process moves dirty pages from the buffer to disk as it frees up buffer space. Lower is better with zero being ideal. When greater than 20, this counter indicates a need for more memory.

Page Lookups/sec -> Should be within 100x of Batch Requests/sec.
=> The number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool. When the ratio of batch requests to page lookups crests 100, you may have inefficient execution plans or too many adhoc queries.

Page Reads/sec -> Less than 90.
=> Number of physical database page reads issued per second. Normal OLTP workloads support 80 - 90 per second, but higher values may be a yellow flag for poor indexing or insufficient memory.

Readahead/sec -> Less than 20% of Page Reads/sec.
=> Number of data pages read per second in anticipation of their use. If this value is makes up even a sizeable minority of total Page Reads/sec (say, greater than 20% of total page reads), you may have too many physical reads occurring.


Checkpoint Pages/sec => Monitors the number of dirty pages, per second, that are flushed to disk when SQL Server invokes the checkpoint process. Checkpoint frequency is influenced by the recovery interval setting in sp_configure. High values for this counter may indicate insufficient memory or that the recovery interval is too high.

Page Writes/sec -> Less than 90.
=> Number of database pages physically written to disk per second. Normal OLTP workloads support 80 – 90 per second. Values over 90 should be crossed checked with “lazy writer/sec” and “checkpoint” counters. If the other counters are also high, then it may indicate insufficient memory
panels.title: SQLServer:Buffer Manager
MSSQL Buffer Manager & Memory Performance Counters

panels.description:
Database Pages => Number of database pages in the buffer pool, as opposed to other usages for memory such as free pages, procedure cache, etc.

Total Server Memory(KB) => Shows the amount of memory that SQL Server is currently using. This value should grow until its equal to Target Server Memory, as it populates its caches and loads pages into memory. When it has finished, SQL Server is said to be in a “steady-state”. Until it is in steady-state, performance may be slow and IO may be higher.

Target Server Memory(KB) => Shows the amount of memory that SQL Server wants to use based on the configured Max Server Memory.
panels.title: SQLServer:Memory Manager

panels.description:
Memory Manager - sql cache memory (kb) => Total amount of dynamic memory the server is using for the dynamic SQL cache

Free Memory (KB) -> More than 640.
=> Total number of pages available across all free lists. A value less than 640 (5MB) indicates physical memory pressure.

Stolen Server Memory (KB) -> Tells how many pages were “stolen” from the buffer pool to satisfy other memory needs, such as plan cache and workspace memory. This number is a good metric to determine how much data is flowing into SQL Server caches and should remain proportionate to “Batch Requests/sec”. Also remember to look for where these stolen pages might be stolen from – optimizer memory, lock memory, and so forth.
panels.title: SQLServer:Memory Manager
MSSQL “How is My Memory Being Used” Performance Counters

panels.description:
Batch Requests/Sec => Number of batch requests received per second, and is a good general indicator for the activity level of the SQL Server.

SQL Compilations/sec -> Less than 10% of the number of Batch Requests/Sec
=> Number of times that Transact-SQL compilations occurred, per second (including recompiles). 
The lower this value is the better. High values often indicate excessive adhoc querying and should be as low as possible. If excessive adhoc querying is happening, try rewriting the queries as procedures or invoke the queries using sp_executeSQL. When rewriting isn’t possible, consider using a plan guide or setting the database to parameterization forced mode.

SQL Re-Compilations/sec -> Less than 10% of the number of SQL Compilations/sec
=> Number of times, per second, that Transact-SQL objects attempted to be executed but had to be recompiled before completion. This number should be at or near zero, since recompiles can cause deadlocks and exclusive compile locks. This counter’s value should follow in proportion to “Batch Requests/sec” and “SQL Compilations/sec”. This needs to be nil in your system as much as possible.
panels.title: SQLServer:SQL Statistics - CPU Stuff

panels.description:
SQL Plans => Cached query plans from adhoc t-sql statements.

Object Plans => Query plans for stored procedures, user defined functions and triggers.

Bound Trees => Normalized trees for views, rules, coomputed columns and check constraint.

Adhoc SQL Plans => Query plans produced from an ad hoc Transact-SQL query, including auto-parameterized queries. SQL Server caches the plans for ad hoc SQL statements for later reuse if the identical Transact-SQL statement is later executed.

Prepared SQL Plans => Query plans that correspond to Transact-SQL statements prepared using sp_prepare, sp_cursorprepare, or auto-parameterization. User-parameterized queries (even if not explicitly prepared) are also monitored as Prepared SQL Plans.

Procedure Plans => Query plans generated by creating a stored procedure.
panels.title: SQLServer: Plan Cache  - Totals

panels.description:
SQL Plans => Cached query plans from adhoc t-sql statements.

Object Plans => Query plans for stored procedures, user defined functions and triggers.

Bound Trees => Normalized trees for views, rules, coomputed columns and check constraint.

Adhoc SQL Plans => Query plans produced from an ad hoc Transact-SQL query, including auto-parameterized queries. SQL Server caches the plans for ad hoc SQL statements for later reuse if the identical Transact-SQL statement is later executed.

Prepared SQL Plans => Query plans that correspond to Transact-SQL statements prepared using sp_prepare, sp_cursorprepare, or auto-parameterization. User-parameterized queries (even if not explicitly prepared) are also monitored as Prepared SQL Plans.

Procedure Plans => Query plans generated by creating a stored procedure.
panels.title: SQLServer: Plan Cache - cache object counts

panels.description:
SQL Plans => Cached query plans from adhoc t-sql statements.

Object Plans => Query plans for stored procedures, user defined functions and triggers.

Bound Trees => Normalized trees for views, rules, coomputed columns and check constraint.

Adhoc SQL Plans => Query plans produced from an ad hoc Transact-SQL query, including auto-parameterized queries. SQL Server caches the plans for ad hoc SQL statements for later reuse if the identical Transact-SQL statement is later executed.

Prepared SQL Plans => Query plans that correspond to Transact-SQL statements prepared using sp_prepare, sp_cursorprepare, or auto-parameterization. User-parameterized queries (even if not explicitly prepared) are also monitored as Prepared SQL Plans.

Procedure Plans => Query plans generated by creating a stored procedure.
panels.title: SQLServer: Plan Cache - cache pages

panels.description:
SQL Plans => Cached query plans from adhoc t-sql statements.

Object Plans => Query plans for stored procedures, user defined functions and triggers.

Bound Trees => Normalized trees for views, rules, coomputed columns and check constraint.

Adhoc SQL Plans => Query plans produced from an ad hoc Transact-SQL query, including auto-parameterized queries. SQL Server caches the plans for ad hoc SQL statements for later reuse if the identical Transact-SQL statement is later executed.

Prepared SQL Plans => Query plans that correspond to Transact-SQL statements prepared using sp_prepare, sp_cursorprepare, or auto-parameterization. User-parameterized queries (even if not explicitly prepared) are also monitored as Prepared SQL Plans.

Procedure Plans => Query plans generated by creating a stored procedure.
panels.title: SQLServer: Plan Cache - cache objects in use
SQL Server : Plan Cache : Cache Manager Instance

panels.description: Longest Running Transaction Time => The time, in seconds, of the longest running transaction. When blocking is high, check this counter to see if transactions are open for long periods of time.
panels.title: Longest Transaction Running Time

targets.rawSql:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;

select pc.collection_time_utc as time, 
		'winsock rejected connections/sec' as metric,
	--object, counter as metric, instance
	pc.value
from $perfmon_table_name pc with (nolock)
where $__timeFilter(collection_time_utc) and pc.host_name = '$perfmon_host_name' and
	 object = 'microsoft winsock bsp' and counter = 'rejected connections/sec'
order by time

list.definition:
select distinct sql_instance from dbo.instance_details
--select srvname from sys.sysservers where providername = 'SQLOLEDB'
list.label: Sql Instance
list.name: server
list.query:
select distinct sql_instance from dbo.instance_details
--select srvname from sys.sysservers where providername = 'SQLOLEDB'

list.label: Host Name
list.name: perfmon_host_name

list.label: Service Name
list.name: perfmon_service_name

list.label: FQDN
list.name: fqdn

list.label: Instance Name
list.name: instance_name

list.label: IP Address
list.name: ip

list.label: Host Name

list.definition:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;
SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER OFF

select top 1 collection_time_utc
from [$inventory_db].$perfmon_table_name
where host_name = '$host_name'
order by collection_time_utc desc
list.label: Collection Time UTC
list.name: collection_time_utc
list.query:
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED;
SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER OFF

select top 1 collection_time_utc
from [$inventory_db].$perfmon_table_name
where host_name = '$host_name'
order by collection_time_utc desc
